metadata.titleEn: Dataset of concentrations of atmospheric and water POPs in Nam Co (2012-2014)
metadata.description: This data set is the concentrations of atmospheric and water POPs in Nam Co, including time series of gas phase OCP, PCBs, PAHs and particulate PAHs in the atmosphere; dissolve and particulate POPs in water. An active air sampler (AAS) was deployed on the roof of Nam Co Monitoring and Research Station for Multisphere Interactions (NCMORS) and the air monitoring was conducted for two consecutive years from September 2012 to September 2014. The flow rate of AAS was 60 L min-1 and the air samples were collected every 2 weeks with a volume of approximately 600 m3 for each sample. The air stream passes first through glass fiber filters (GFFs 0.7 μm, Whatman) to collect the total suspended particulates (TSP) and then through polyurethane foam (PUF, 7.5×6 cm diameter) to retain the POPs in gas phase. Fifteen sites around the Nam Co Lake (surface lake water, 0–1 m depth) were selected to obtain the spatial distribution of POPs in lake water. The water samples (200 L) were filtered with GFFs to obtain the total suspended particulate matter (SPM), and then pumped through an XAD-2 resin column to collect the dissolved phase compounds. All the samples were analyzed at Key Laboratory of Tibetan Environment Changes and Land Surface Processes, Chinese Academy of Sciences. The samples were Soxhlet-extracted, purified on an aluminium/silica column (i.d. 8 mm), a gel permeation chromatography (GPC) column subsequently, and were detected on a gas chromatograph with an ion-trap mass spectrometer (GC-MS, Finnigan Trace GC/PolarisQ) operating under MS–MS mode.  A CP-Sil 8CB capillary column (50 m ×0.25 mm, film thickness 0.25 μm) was used for OCPs and PCBs and a DB-5MS column (60 m ×0.25mm, film thickness 0.25 μm) was used for PAHs. Field blanks and procedural blanks were prepared. The recoveries ranged from 64% to 112% for OCPs, and 65% to 92% forPAHs. The reported concentrations were not corrected for recoveries.
metadata.instructions: This data can be opened and analysed with Excel software.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods for measuring persistent organic pollutants in atmospheric and aquatic environments?
Feature Specification.Answer: 60 L min-1 flow rate, every other day sampling, approximately every half month, 600 m3 sample volume, 0.45 μm glass fiber filters, polyurethane foam, 15 sampling points, 0-1 m depth, 200 L water sample, 0.7 μm GFF membrane, solid-phase extraction column with XAD-2, Soxhlet extraction, silica-alumina column purification, GPC column, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) system

Quantification.Question: What is the total number of atmospheric samples collected for analyzing persistent organic pollutants concentrations?

Definition.Question: What is the process of collecting atmospheric and lake water samples for persistent organic pollutants (POPs) concentration analysis?
Definition.Answer: The process involves using an atmospheric active sampler to collect atmospheric samples at a flow rate of 60 L min-1, with samples collected every other day and each sample representing about 600 m3. Each atmospheric sample includes a glass fiber filter membrane for particle-bound POPs and a polyurethane foam for gaseous POPs. Lake water samples are collected from 15 sampling sites around the lake, with each surface water sample taken from a depth of 0-1 m and having a volume of 200 L. The water samples are filtered to obtain total suspended particulates and then enriched for dissolved POPs using XAD-2 filled solid phase extraction columns.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for specific sampling and processing techniques when measuring concentrations of persistent organic pollutants in atmospheric and aquatic environments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for specific sampling and processing techniques arises from the necessity to accurately capture and measure the concentrations of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) in different media such as air and water. This involves using atmospheric active samplers with precise flow rates to collect gaseous and particulate POPs, and employing solid-phase extraction for dissolved POPs in water. The complexity of these methods is due to the low concentration levels of POPs, the variability of environmental conditions, and the requirement for rigorous quality control measures to ensure data reliability and accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the instrumental and procedural steps involved in collecting and analyzing persistent organic pollutants in atmospheric and lake water samples?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves using atmospheric active samplers at a flow rate of 60 L min-1, collecting samples every other day, with each sample representing a half-month period and a sampling volume of approximately 600 m3. Each atmospheric sample includes glass fiber filters (GFF) for particle-bound POPs and polyurethane foam (PUF) for gaseous POPs. Lake water samples are collected from 15 surface water sites around the lake, with a water depth of 0-1 m and a sample volume of 200 L each. Water samples are first filtered through 0.7 μm GFF to obtain total suspended particles, then dissolved POPs are enriched using XAD-2 filled solid-phase extraction columns. Sample pretreatment includes Soxhlet extraction, silica-alumina column purification, GPC column to remove large molecular impurities, and concentration. Analysis is conducted using a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) with chromatographic columns specific for OCPs, PCBs, and PAHs. Quality control includes laboratory and field blanks, with PAHs recovery rates between 65-92% and OCPs recovery rates between 64-112%, with concentrations not corrected for recovery rates.

Enablement.Question: What collection techniques enable the acquisition of time-series concentration data of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) in both atmospheric and lacustrine environments?
Enablement.Answer: The collection techniques involve using atmospheric active samplers at a flow rate of 60 L min-1 to collect samples every other day, resulting in one sample every half month with a volume of approximately 600 m3. These samples include glass fiber filters (GFF, 0.45 μm) for particulate POPs and polyurethane foam (PUF, 7.5×6 cm) for gaseous POPs. Lacustrine samples are collected from 15 surface water points around a lake at a depth of 0-1 m, with each sample having a volume of 200 L. The water samples are filtered through a 0.7 μm GFF membrane to obtain total suspended particulates and enriched with XAD-2 filled solid phase extraction columns for dissolved POPs.
